Part A: Describe one feature of the representations of African Americans on the stage or screen in the twentieth century.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • An increase in the depiction of African Americans in television that attempted to capture the diversity within the culture in the 1970s and 1980s.

  • Filmmakers like Oscar Micheaux presented Black life and characters as realistic and complex.

  • All-Black casts performed a range of roles that challenged negative stereotypes.

  • Black theater included prominent depictions of Black joy.

  • Shows like The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air portrayed upward mobility in the Black community.

  • Television series such as Good Times portrayed strong African American family units.

  • Afrofuturistic films often depict an Afrocentric future that features African Americans as experts in advanced science and technology.

The response accomplishes the task set by part A of the question.

Part B: Explain how a historical context could have influenced the way African Americans were represented, such as that depicted in the source.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The series A Different World highlights how the founding of HBCUs transformed African Americans’ access to higher education, which allowed many to rise out of poverty and become leaders in society.

  • The depiction of Hillman College reflects how real HBCUs created spaces for cultural pride and Black scholarship.

  • The depiction of step in the source reflects the prominence of Black Greek-letter organizations at HBCUs, which created spaces for African American students to support one another.

  • The Black Arts and Black Campus movements encouraged African Americans to embrace, study, and promote aspects of their cultural heritage.

The response accomplishes the task set by part B of the question.

Part C: Explain how depictions of African Americans in the performing arts could be useful sources for African American Studies scholars.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • African American Studies utilizes an interdisciplinary approach; therefore, the representation of African Americans in art by Black artists is a valuable source for understanding how African Americans view themselves.

  • Ethnic studies research benefits from sources that include the depiction of African Americans in the performing arts because they show how Black people are viewed in popular culture.

  • Utilizing artwork helps scholars take an interdisciplinary approach to scholarly inquiry.
